segments.text: Um, how did the war and the dropping of the bomb, how has that affected you after you got out of the service and up to today?
Well, I think the experiences of the war are, they had a great meaning to me at the time and they still, and still do.
it was a time of sacrifice for everyone.
Those overseas doing what they were called upon to do there and wanted back home.
Everybody was in the mood to sacrifice, and they did.
And once the war ended, you know, at that point your mind turned to, you know, let's go home with my family, pick up life, and get started again.
I was still
Twenty-one at the time.
And I thought, well, twenty-two at the time, excuse me.
And I thought, well, I've got to complete my education, and I'm married, I've got to get a career going here.
So I can provide for my family and enjoy this peace that we have preserved, so to speak.
I'm grateful really for the opportunity that I had to serve.
They were great experiences, maturing experiences.
In a time like that you can go from a kid to a man pretty quickly.
It doesn't make any difference what your age is.
When the time comes that you're required to be a man, and if you step up to it,
and do a man's work does something to you.
You mature.
A lot of times I think we never get that opportunity.
And I'm glad I had it because I think it's probably helped me all my life.
Separate the real meaningful things from the shallow things.
Worldly.
Yeah.
And so...
it had a great meaning to me.
I really wanted to get back and get going.
So I was released from the service in May of 1946.
I entered SMU in June of 1946.
And prior to the war, I had 18 hours of college credits.
So I started in June of 1946, and in August of 48, 26 months later,
I had a bachelor of business administration degree from SMU.
And I worked day and night, had night classes, day classes, wherever I could get a job.
And I worked classes around that.
And my dear companion worked.
And we just, we went through this age.
I lost about 30 pounds during that 26 months going to school, working and studying and doing
I wanted to get it done.
I was in a hurry to get it done.
It was like you jump out of that airplane at the end of the war running.
Go.
And so I did that.
And I pretty well knew what I wanted to do.
I wanted to be in the line of work that I got in and studied for.
And have been successful, relatively.
I retired six weeks ago.
And I reached the level of Vice President in my company and had success there.
I had more than one career.
I was in real estate development and another career.
And then came back to my original career and retired there.
So I had a measure of success, you know.
Nothing spectacular, but satisfying to me.
That's success.
I had a very happy life.
Just before I graduated from SMU, our first child was born, our daughter.
And then four years later, our son.
So life's been good.
I've been full.
It's been meaningful.
We've been devoted to church work and to doing the work of the Lord for many years.
And it's just been happy.
Peaceful, happy, joyful.
Love my children, love my grandchildren.
I think one of my greatest roles in life is to be a grandfather.
I love to be a grandfather.
Love to sit and talk with them.
They think I'm an old relic.
But they like to hear some of my stories.
Of course.
And I don't mind being an old relic.
I suppose I enjoy my life today as much as I have ever enjoyed any time in my whole life.
Well, that's super.
And I expect to enjoy my future years even better.
Well, retired is one way to definitely enjoy them.
For sure.
I'd like to retire at 24, but I don't know if that's going to be possible.
Brother Gress, I've got one more question for you.
When you look back at your experiences in war, and you were stationed, I take it, at Guam, overseas, what
were like the main problems that were encountered on the ground between soldiers, between the men on the ground?
What were the greatest conflicts as the war was winding down, the bombs being dropped?
What were kind of conflicts, kind of frogging of officers?
No, nothing like that.
As far as, we had a small group.
There was about, at the height of the war, we had, I believe, as I remember, we had 21 crews.
Most of us were flying B-29s, but some of them flew B-24s and did radio jamming and picking up signals, interpreting signals and things of that nature.
And so we were all kind of close.
We had our own group.
separate from the big 20th Air Force headquarters, our own officer's club and everything.
We had our wing headquarters were back in Honolulu and our group headquarters in Denver, Colorado.
off and then bring back bomb bays full of liquor and all kinds of things like this.
And there was a lot of drinking.
There was, with 21 crews in the war over, we didn't have a lot of flying to do.
We'd ferry troops, we'd do all kinds of things.
But as far as our normal mission, there was nothing to do.
We did fly around and do some aerial photography on some different islands out of the Pacific just so they'd have the photographs and do things.
And they proved very valuable later.
But we were idle a lot.
We'd go for maybe sometimes a week, maybe once in a while, even two weeks, and never fly.
And so you really didn't have any duties.
And so we would organize.
physical education clubs.
We got to play volleyball.
It's hot on Guam.
And you'd have to do that either early in the morning or you couldn't get anybody out to do it.
So we spent a lot of time at the officer's club in the daytime.
You know, guys would drink, get into arguments, and they might, you know, swing, take a couple swings at one another.
But nothing serious ever really came in our entire group.
There was not any disrespect of officers, but we respected the officers.
They would help us.
They started shipping everybody home on the basis of seniority and length of time overseas.
Well, I was the young kid on the block, so to speak, and the war was over about six months before I ever came home.
So I spent about six months just kind of wasting time goofing around.
Tried to read a lot.

whatever you know pastime and do slept a lot so it seems to me like the biggest problem was boredom well yeah because it just wasn't that much to do we'd go to the motor pool and get a truck or whatever we get and we just loaded full we just drive around the island just sightseeing and see things go down the beach and spend the whole day down there take some food with us learn on the beach and just just have fun you know
Just to do whatever you could find, anything you could find to do, you'd go do it.
That's super.
Brother Grass, I appreciate the interview.
I hope that other people get something out of it like I have.
It's been great.
I've enjoyed reliving the experience, Frankie.
It's been fun for me, too.
I've enjoyed it.
Well, thank you very much.
Thank you.
